It depends also where it falls. So considering the cookie contact area with the ground. If the specific density of pathogens is low and then one adds the rules you had mentioned, i.e., contact area and slowness of the motion for wet vs dry specimen, then the danger is low. The problem remains. Can one judge successfully among surfaces? Often he can. But when it comes to judgement there is another decision: considering the urgency. Low urgency -- Don't! Starvation--yes. To conclude, as always, one has to consider the risk vs the benefit/urgency.

In my opinion there are 2 answers to this depending on what the food falls on.

If it falls on a dry floor that only had a few germs per square mm then while the food will have lots of germs if you ate it the germ count would be too low to cause disease. If the food fell on say some dog pooh then there would be enough germs transferred to cause disease even if eaten immediately.
